habitat_description:
Southeast:
Scalopus aquaticus anastasae is known only from Anastasia Island at St. Augustine FL. However, Whitaker and Hamilton (1998) state that the status for this subspecies is questionable but maintain the taxonomy because of the isolated nature of the records. GBIF (2014) contains only five records on Anastasia Island, four dating from 1901 and one from 1955. Although there is no state or federal status for this subspecies, NatureServe ranks the Anastasia Island mole as globally critically imperiled. Habitat for the subspecies is similar to the full species - losse, sandy, and sand loam soils in a variety of vegetation types while avoiding inundated environments and soils not conducive to burrowing such as clay, gravel, or exceedingly dry types (Yates and Schmidly, Trani et al. 2007, Whitaker and Hamilton 1998).
